title: Luke Annear
text:
I’m currently a PhD student in the Language Sciences program at the University of Wisconsin - Madison.
I study how children acquire the speech sounds of their native language, and am currently focusing on how children acquire laryngeal contrasts (like voicing, aspiration) cross-linguistically. Zoomed out, I am interested in how phonological structure is built during development, and how the mental categories created influence how we say things. To this end, my work intersects the fields of Communication Sciences and Disorders and Linguistics through the belief that gaining insights into these developmental processes underlies best practices in treatment and therapy for Speech Sound Disorders.
In the past I’ve also done work in the field of Tolkien studies, which you’ll see reflected in prior publications. If you’re wondering where all of the carp fishing information has gone, please visit freshwaterflats.com

title: Research
text:
Understanding contrast
One part of my research focuses on contrasts like pizza/bizza in example 5 above. English (and German, Mandarin, etc.) uses a puff of air on p to distinguish it from b, and in English children tend to learn b before they learn p. However, Dutch (French, Italian, etc.) uses a lot of voicing/phonation on b (kind of like mb) to distinguish it from p, and in Dutch children tend to learn p before they learn b. This line of research explores the ways that these patterns across languages are both similar and different.
